results.notes: On dead conifer twig (Abies/Picea most likely). Green granular crust with abundant, tiny apothecia (approx. 0.1 mm in diameter). Apothecia have yellowish disks with white margins. Spot tests negative. UV was interesting: apothecia UV+ bright white (more prominent than picture shows), but there were also abundant bright red areas on thallus – not sure what that could be. Perhaps a particular kind of algae?

results.notes: on dead conifer twig (Picea/Abies). Not really sure if this is a lichen – appears to be lichenized, or at least, there is a discernible algal layer. Could not discern any kind of reproductive structure(s). Spot tests negative, but UV+ bright bluish white. Perhaps this is something that died, the white stuff anyway? Under the microscope, you can see what appears to be hyphae sticking straight up from the upper surface of the “thallus”.

results.notes:
Growing abundantly on the sides and underside of a decorticated hardwood log. Caps pruinose with translucent-striate margins; without shaggy tomentum. Pileipellis a loose ixocutis. Clamps present in all tissues and abundant. Cheilocystidia with tapering projections and hyaline. Metuloids absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth, hyaline, subglobose and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4) 4.2 – 5.2 (5.7) √ó (3.5) 4 – 4.7 (5.2) ¬µm; Q = 1 – 1.2 (1.3); N = 30; Me = 4.7 √ó 4.3 ¬µm; Qe = 1.1

results.notes:
Growing on the underside of a hardwood log. The log was very hard. Hairs yellow in mass. Red-brown guttation present around ascocarps. Individual hairs with brown intracellular pigment toward bases and hyaline toward apices; smooth at apices and granulate toward bases. Paraphyses narrowly lanceolate; hyaline. Asci unitunicate, inoperculate, 8-spored, with croziers and amyloid apical plugs. Ascus measurements: (50.1) 59.8 – 70.8 (71.9) √ó (4.3) 4.4 – 5.4 (5.5) ¬µm; Q = (10.7) 11.3 – 15.1 (15.9); N = 20; Me = 64.6 √ó 5 ¬µm; Qe = 13. Spores smooth, hyaline and 0-septate. Spore measurements: (5.5) 5.6 – 7.5 (8) √ó (1.5) 1.7 – 2.7 (2.9) ¬µm, Q = (2.5) 2.7 – 3.7 (4.3); N = 30, Me = 6.7 √ó 2.1 ¬µm; Qe = 3.3.

Growing abundantly on Hamamelis virginiana and Quercus sp. leaves near Nyssa sylvatica, Fagus grandifolia, Liriodendron tulipifera, Magnolia acuminata, Hamamelis virginiana, Prunus serotina, Quercus rubra, Quercus alba and Acer saccharum. Black veil-like covering splitting to reveal apothecia. Paraphyses coiled. Asci inamyloid, inoperculate and 8-spored. Spores hyaline, smooth, cylindrical, thin-walled and 0-septate. Spore measurements: (26.9) 29.6 – 40.2 (42.2) √ó (2.6) 2.8 – 3.9 (4.5) ¬µm; Q = (7.3) 8.6 – 11.6 (12.6); N = 30; Me = 34.5 √ó 3.4 ¬µm; Qe = 10.2

results.notes: Hi, everyone. I am new in this comunitee. I was being told to go to this website where maybe I could get answer to the fungi that I found. They grew on my Flamboyant tree. I found them in November 2021, still in the small size, but yesterday when I checked again, they have spread themselves circling around the tree. What fungi are these? I just know that perhaps it is Ganoderma, but I dont know what is the exact species name of it. Is it edible or is it poisonous, if it is poisonous, should I becareful not to touch them? I tried to contact local mushroom observer in Indonesia, they didnt give any news about them. I didnt know that mushroom can live instead of my dying tree. I want to keep them and try to plant them in a good media if I know how and what are their character and habitat should be.

results.notes:
Fruiting beneath Western red cedar and Douglas fir. Western red cedar dominant canopy.

Harvested 11 specimens for further study/microscopy.

Microscopy Performed(all images of work included):
Setae: present(see images included).
SPORES: TAPERED AT TIPS.
SPORES: 9,10,12 Septate.
Performed Crush Mount in Lugol‚Äôs solution to analyze paraphyses and Asci.
PARAPHYSES: curved tips, swollen tips, coiled. Distinctly longer than asci(see images of work).
ASCI: 8 spored.
Dehydrated all 11 specimens and bagged/labeled for herbarium collection.

results.notes:
Growing on a hardwood log in a woodpile. Faint fruit-loop-like odor – “sweet” according to Jacob Kalichman. All structures inamyloid. Dimitic with clamped generative hyphae. Hyphal tips in the dissepiments (sp.?) lightly encrusted. Cystidioles present in the hymenium. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores hyaline and allantoid. Spore measurements: (3.3) 3.5 – 4.5 (4.8) √ó 1.1 – 1.3 (1.5) ¬µm; Q = (2.9) 3 – 3.7 (3.9); N = 18; Me = 4 √ó 1.2 ¬µm; Qe = 3.3

results.notes: Specimens were observed growing on dead branches of an oak tree. I used a table saw to make longitudinal cuts through the branch and mushroom simultaneously. Upon further inspection, I found some tunnels from a wood-boring insect, filled with “sawdust”. One of these tunnels had a 90-degree turn which led directly to the attachment point of the mushroom. At the base of the mushroom, I found a living larva with a white body and a brown head with pinching jaws. I’m assuming that this was some kind of ant or termite.

results.notes:
Macro: thallus continuous-areolate, surface varying from dark gray to whitish. Apothecia black, some with a hint of light gray pruina, slightly sunken/concave, mostly 1/areole but some with 2. Rims of apothecia generally concolorous with thallus. Prothallus fairly prominent, dark gray and glossy. Micro: hymenium ~150 micrometers tall including epihymenium. Epihymenium green. Paraphyses moniliform. Conidia measured 14-20 (14,16,17,20, 16,18,17,19,14) micrometers long. Pycnidia black at surface.

Spores 8/ascus. Ovoid, 24.5×15.5, 25×15, 24×12 micrometers

Chemistry: thallus K- in section

Habitat: coastal non-calcarous sandstone outcrop on coastal terrace among coastal scrub and coastal grassland.

When I try to key this out in the Sonoran Flora, I get to the A. fumosa/cyanescens couplet. A. fumosa doesn’t seem to fit because the apothecia are quite small and don’t seem to consistently have a dark thalline rim, the areoles with apothecia are not prominent, and the thallus color is generally quite dark gray. A. cyanescens on the other hand doesn’t seem like a great fit because of the conidia measurements (none measured greater than 20-21 micrometers), and the lack of an obvious blue tint in the prothallus/epihymenium/thallus in general.

results.notes:
Habitat: Fruiting in moss and woody debris beneath Western red cedar(Thuja plicata). Many fruiting bodies attached to moss/woody debris.
Fruiting bodies: 3.9-5.8cm tall.
Cap: black, smooth clearly separate from stem.
Stem:smooth with young specimens, squamulose/scaly in dry older specimens.
SCALES/SQUAMULES EASILY REMOVED.
Many fruiting in clusters of 3 and 2(caespitose) with moss attached to mycelium at bases.
Mycelium: gray.
NOT HAIRY.
Harvested 10 specimens for microscopy/further study.

Microscopy: performed crush mount in NH40H and also analyzed ejected/mature spores on separate slides dry.
Images of work included.
Spores: all 7 Septate. Short, cylindrical, blunt.
NO SETAE PRESENT in this collection.
Asci: 8 spored.
Paraphyses: curved at tips, most all are septate, many have downturned tips(swollen).
Paraphyses septa only slightly constricted.
Dehydrated all 10 specimens and bagged for herbarium collection.

results.notes:
Encrusting the bases of 2 Quercus sect. Quercus trees. Carya sp., Quercus sect. Lobatae, Acer sp., Broussonetia papyrifera, Ilex opaca and a Pinus sapling present nearby. Texture fleshy. Hyphae, basidia and spores lacking a reaction in 1M KOH. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Cystidia absent. Spores spiny, brown, thick-walled, lobate and angular. Spore measurements: (7.1) 7.5 – 9 (12.2) √ó (5.8) 6 – 7.3 (9.4) ¬µml; Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.4 (1.5); N = 30; Me = 8.5 √ó 6.7 ¬µm; Qe = 1.3. Spine length measurements: (1) 1.1 – 1.7 (1.9) ¬µm; N = 25; Me = 1.4 ¬µm

—

results.notes:
Effused-reflexed and encrusting hardwood twigs, leaves, soil and a the base of a small Ulmus sapling. Quercus sect. Quercus, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Fagus grandifolia, Ilex opaca, Aesculus sp., Liriodendron tulipifera and Acer saccharum present nearby. Odor slightly fishy – “Slightly briny” according to Jacob Kalichman. Basidia, spores and hyphae lacking reaction in 1M KOH. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores spiny, brown, lobate and angular. Spore measurements: (6.4) 7.6 – 9 (9.4) √ó (5.4) 6.9 – 8.2 (8.5) ¬µm; Q = 1 – 1.2 (1.3); N = 30; Me = 8.3 √ó 7.3 ¬µm; Qe = 1.1

results.notes:
Habitat: Mixed pine, eastern red cedar, hardwoods, ground
Cap: 5.4 cm, convex, yellow brown, disk smooth, rugose toward margin, veil material on cap margin (white squares, floccose), context white then light brown, brownish under disk
Gills: white, crowded, lamellulae diverse lengths, free or adnexed
Stipe: 10 cm length, apex 9 mm, base 15 mm, white, fibrous, reddish-brown stains, basal 4 cm covered in white mycelium, rhizomorphs white; flesh white, no staining, solid
Partial veil: ring of white squares topped with brown, 3.5 cm below apex
Odor: farinaceous
Spore print: white

results.notes:
It was growing in a garden in front of a house…

Very very close to the Humedal Cordoba woods…

There was a cluster of this mushrooms growing one next to the other not so big as usual Suillus I had seen in other parts. Ive also had never seen so many Boletales mushrooms growing next to the other I just picked two… I did not have a camera in the moment so I brought them to my house and took the photos… I actually went out for a walk and to read… I was not looking for mushrooms. Not so usual this month… Some rains this early February but not so many observations but this one was beautiful…
